t: Song of Solomon 1
The Young Shulammite Bride and Jerusalem’s Daughters
The*p Song of Songs, which is Solomon’s.
“May*pn he kiss me with the kisses of his mouth! For*ln your love is better than wine.
Your*ln oils have a pleasing fragrance, Your*ln name is like*i purified oil; Therefore*ln the maidens love you.

Draw*ln me after you and*i let us run together!*i The*ln king has brought me into his chambers.” “We*bln will rejoice in you and be glad; We*ln will extol your love more than wine. Rightly*ln do they love you.”
“I*ln am black but lovely, O*ln daughters of Jerusalem, Like*ln the tents of Kedar, Like*ln the curtains of Solomon.

Do*ln not stare at me because I am swarthy, For*ln the sun has burned me. My*ln mother’s sons were angry with me; They*ln made me caretaker of the vineyards, But*iln I have not taken care of my own vineyard.

Tell*ln me, O you whom my soul loves, Where*ln do you pasture your*i flock,*i Where*ln do you make it*i lie down at noon? For*ln why should I be like one who veils herself Beside*ln the flocks of your companions?”
Solomon, the Lover, Speaks
“If*pn you yourself do not know, Most*ln beautiful among women, Go*ln forth on the trail of the flock And*ln pasture your young goats By*ln the tents of the shepherds.
“To*ln me, my darling, you are like My*ln mare among the chariots of Pharaoh.
Your*ln cheeks are lovely with ornaments, Your*ln neck with strings of beads.”
“We*ln will make for you ornaments of gold With*ln beads of silver.”
“While*ln the king was at his table, My*ln perfume gave forth its fragrance.
My*ln beloved is to me a pouch of myrrh Which*ln lies all night between my breasts.
My*ln beloved is to me a cluster of henna blossoms In*ln the vineyards of Engedi.”
“How*ln beautiful you are, my darling, How*ln beautiful you are! Your*ln eyes are like*i doves.”
“How*ln handsome you are, my beloved, And*iln so pleasant! Indeed,*ln our couch is luxuriant!
The*ln beams of our houses are cedars, Our*ln rafters, cypresses.
Song of Solomon 2
The Bride’s Admiration
“I*pn am the rose of Sharon, The*ln lily of the valleys.”
“Like*ln a lily among the thorns, So*ln is my darling among the maidens.”
“Like*ln an apple tree among the trees of the forest, So*ln is my beloved among the young men. In*ln his shade I took great delight and sat down, And*ln his fruit was sweet to my taste.
He*ln has brought me to his*i banquet hall, And*ln his banner over me is love.
Sustain*ln me with raisin cakes, Refresh*ln me with apples, Because*ln I am lovesick.
Let*ln his left hand be under my head And*ln his right hand embrace me.”
“I*ln adjure you, O daughters of Jerusalem, By*ln the gazelles or by the hinds of the field, That*ln you do not arouse or awaken my*i love Until*ln she pleases.”
“Listen!*ln My beloved! Behold,*ln he is coming, Climbing*ln on the mountains, Leaping*ln on the hills!
My*ln beloved is like a gazelle or a young stag. Behold,*ln he is standing behind our wall, He*ln is looking through the windows, He*ln is peering through the lattice.
“My*ln beloved responded and said to me, ‘Arise,*ln my darling, my beautiful one, And*ln come along.
For*ln behold, the winter is past, The*ln rain is over and*i gone.
The*ln flowers have already*i appeared in the land; The*ln time has arrived for pruning the*i vines,*i And*ln the voice of the turtledove has been heard in our land.
The*ln fig tree has ripened its figs, And*ln the vines in blossom have given forth their*i fragrance. Arise,*ln my darling, my beautiful one, And*ln come along!’ ”
“O*ln my dove, in the clefts of the rock, In*ln the secret place of the steep pathway, Let*ln me see your form, Let*ln me hear your voice; For*ln your voice is sweet, And*ln your form is lovely.”
“Catch*ln the foxes for us, The*ln little foxes that are ruining the vineyards, While*ln our vineyards are in blossom.”
“My*ln beloved is mine, and I am his; He*ln pastures his*i flock*i among the lilies.
Until*ln the cool of the day when the shadows flee away, Turn,*ln my beloved, and be like a gazelle Or*ln a young stag on the mountains of Bether.”
Song of Solomon 3
The Bride’s Troubled Dream
“On*pn my bed night after night I sought him Whom*ln my soul loves; I*ln sought him but did not find him.
‘I*ln must arise now and go about the city; In*ln the streets and in the squares I*ln must seek him whom my soul loves.’ I*ln sought him but did not find him.
The*ln watchmen who make the rounds in the city found me, And*iln I*i said,*i ‘Have you seen him whom my soul loves?’

Scarcely*ln had I left them When*ln I found him whom my soul loves; I*ln held on to him and would not let him go Until*ln I had brought him to my mother’s house, And*ln into the room of her who conceived me.”
“I*ln adjure you, O daughters of Jerusalem, By*ln the gazelles or by the hinds of the field, That*ln you will not arouse or awaken my*i love Until*ln she pleases.”
Solomon’s Wedding Day
“What*pn is this coming up from the wilderness Like*ln columns of smoke, Perfumed*ln with myrrh and frankincense, With*ln all scented powders of the merchant?
Behold,*ln it is the traveling*i couch of Solomon; Sixty*ln mighty men around it, Of*ln the mighty men of Israel.
All*ln of them are wielders of the sword, Expert*ln in war; Each*ln man has his sword at his side, Guarding*iln against the terrors of the night.
King*ln Solomon has made for himself a sedan chair From*ln the timber of Lebanon.
He*ln made its posts of silver, Its*ln back of gold And*iln its seat of purple fabric, With*iln its interior lovingly fitted out By*ln the daughters of Jerusalem.
Go*ln forth, O daughters of Zion, And*ln gaze on King Solomon with the crown With*ln which his mother has crowned him On*ln the day of his wedding, And*ln on the day of his gladness of heart.”
Song of Solomon 4
Solomon’s Love Expressed
“How*pn beautiful you are, my darling, How*ln beautiful you are! Your*ln eyes are like*i doves behind your veil; Your*ln hair is like a flock of goats That*ln have descended from Mount Gilead.
Your*ln teeth are like a flock of newly*i shorn ewes Which*ln have come up from their*i washing, All*ln of which bear twins, And*ln not one among them has lost her young.
Your*ln lips are like a scarlet thread, And*ln your mouth is lovely. Your*ln temples are like a slice of a pomegranate Behind*ln your veil.
Your*ln neck is like the tower of David, Built*ln with rows of stones On*ln which are hung a thousand shields, All*ln the round shields of the mighty men.
Your*ln two breasts are like two fawns, Twins*ln of a gazelle Which*ln feed among the lilies.
Until*ln the cool of the day When*ln the shadows flee away, I*ln will go my way to the mountain of myrrh And*ln to the hill of frankincense.
“You*ln are altogether beautiful, my darling, And*ln there is no blemish in you.

Come*iln with me from Lebanon, my*i bride, May*ln you come with me from Lebanon. Journey*ln down from the summit of Amana, From*ln the summit of Senir and Hermon, From*ln the dens of lions, From*ln the mountains of leopards.
You*ln have made my heart beat faster, my sister, my*i bride; You*ln have made my heart beat faster with a single glance*i of your eyes, With*ln a single strand of your necklace.
How*ln beautiful is your love, my sister, my*i bride! How*ln much better is your love than wine, And*ln the fragrance of your oils Than*ln all kinds*i of spices!
Your*ln lips, my*i bride, drip honey; Honey*ln and milk are under your tongue, And*ln the fragrance of your garments is like the fragrance of Lebanon.
A*ln garden locked is my sister, my*i bride, A*ln rock garden locked, a spring sealed up.
Your*ln shoots are an orchard of pomegranates With*ln choice fruits, henna with nard plants,
Nard*ln and saffron, calamus and cinnamon, With*ln all the trees of frankincense, Myrrh*ln and aloes, along with all the finest spices.
You*iln are*i a garden spring, A*ln well of fresh water, And*ln streams flowing*i from Lebanon.”

“Awake,*ln O north wind,*i And*ln come, wind*i of*i the south; Make*ln my garden breathe out fragrance,*i Let*ln its spices be wafted abroad. May*ln my beloved come into his garden And*ln eat its choice fruits!”
Song of Solomon 5
The Torment of Separation

“I*pn have come into my garden, my sister, my*i bride; I*ln have gathered my myrrh along with my balsam. I*ln have eaten my honeycomb and my honey; I*ln have drunk my wine and my milk. Eat,*ln friends; Drink*ln and imbibe deeply, O lovers.”

“I*ln was asleep but my heart was awake. A*ln voice! My beloved was knocking: ‘Open*ln to me, my sister, my darling, My*ln dove, my perfect one! For*ln my head is drenched with dew, My*ln locks with the damp of the night.’
I*ln have taken off my dress, How*ln can I put it on again?*i I*ln have washed my feet, How*ln can I dirty them again?*i
My*ln beloved extended his hand through the opening, And*ln my feelings were aroused for him.
I*ln arose to open to my beloved; And*ln my hands dripped with myrrh, And*ln my fingers with liquid myrrh, On*ln the handles of the bolt.

I*ln opened to my beloved, But*ln my beloved had turned away and*i had gone! My*ln heart went out to*i him*i as he spoke. I*ln searched for him but I did not find him; I*ln called him but he did not answer me.
The*ln watchmen who make the rounds in the city found me, They*ln struck me and*i wounded me; The*ln guardsmen of the walls took away my shawl from me.
I*ln adjure you, O daughters of Jerusalem, If*ln you find my beloved, As*ln to what you will tell him: For*ln I am lovesick.”
“What*ln kind of beloved is your beloved, O*ln most beautiful among women? What*ln kind of beloved is your beloved, That*ln thus you adjure us?”
Admiration by the Bride
“My*pn beloved is dazzling and ruddy, Outstanding*ln among ten thousand.
His*ln head is like*i gold, pure gold; His*ln locks are like*i clusters of dates And*iln black as a raven.
His*ln eyes are like doves Beside*ln streams of water, Bathed*ln in milk, And*iln reposed in their*i setting.
His*ln cheeks are like a bed of balsam, Banks*ln of sweet-scented herbs; His*ln lips are lilies Dripping*ln with liquid myrrh.
His*ln hands are rods of gold Set*ln with beryl; His*ln abdomen is carved ivory Inlaid*ln with sapphires.
His*ln legs are pillars of alabaster Set*ln on pedestals of pure gold; His*ln appearance is like Lebanon Choice*ln as the cedars.
His*ln mouth is full*i of*i sweetness. And*ln he is wholly desirable. This*ln is my beloved and this is my friend, O*ln daughters of Jerusalem.”
Song of Solomon 6
Mutual Delight in Each Other
“Where*pn has your beloved gone, O*ln most beautiful among women? Where*ln has your beloved turned, That*ln we may seek him with you?”
“My*ln beloved has gone down to his garden, To*ln the beds of balsam, To*ln pasture his*i flock*i in the gardens And*ln gather lilies.
I*ln am my beloved’s and my beloved is mine, He*ln who pastures his*i flock*i among the lilies.”
“You*ln are as beautiful as Tirzah, my darling, As*ln lovely as Jerusalem, As*ln awesome as an army with banners.
Turn*ln your eyes away from me, For*ln they have confused me; Your*ln hair is like a flock of goats That*ln have descended from Gilead.
Your*ln teeth are like a flock of ewes Which*ln have come up from their*i washing, All*ln of which bear twins, And*ln not one among them has lost her young.
Your*ln temples are like a slice of a pomegranate Behind*ln your veil.
There*ln are sixty queens and eighty concubines, And*ln maidens without number;

But*iln my dove, my perfect one, is unique: She*ln is her mother’s only daughter;*i She*ln is the pure child*i of the one who bore her. The*ln maidens saw her and called her blessed, The*ln queens and the concubines also,*i and they praised her, saying,*i
‘Who*ln is this that grows like the dawn, As*ln beautiful as the full moon, As*ln pure as the sun, As*ln awesome as an army with banners?’
I*ln went down to the orchard of nut trees To*ln see the blossoms of the valley, To*ln see whether the vine had budded Or*iln the pomegranates had bloomed.
Before*ln I was aware, my soul set me Over*iln the chariots of my noble people.”
“Come*ln back, come back, O Shulammite; Come*ln back, come back, that we may gaze at you!” “Why*bln should you gaze at the Shulammite, As*ln at the dance of the two companies?
Song of Solomon 7
Admiration by the Bridegroom
“How*pn beautiful are your feet in sandals, O*ln prince’s daughter! The*ln curves of your hips are like jewels, The*ln work of the hands of an artist.
Your*ln navel is like*i a round goblet Which*ln never lacks mixed wine; Your*ln belly is like a heap of wheat Fenced*ln about with lilies.
Your*ln two breasts are like two fawns, Twins*ln of a gazelle.
Your*ln neck is like a tower of ivory, Your*ln eyes like*i the pools in Heshbon By*ln the gate of Bath-rabbim; Your*ln nose is like the tower of Lebanon, Which*ln faces toward Damascus.
Your*ln head crowns you like Carmel, And*ln the flowing locks of your head are like purple threads; The*iln king is captivated by your*i tresses.
How*ln beautiful and how delightful you are, My*iln love, with all*i your charms!
Your*ln stature is like a palm tree, And*ln your breasts are like*i its*i clusters.
I*ln said, ‘I will climb the palm tree, I*ln will take hold of its fruit stalks.’ Oh,*ln may your breasts be like clusters of the vine, And*ln the fragrance of your breath like apples,
And*ln your mouth like the best wine!” “It*bln goes down*i smoothly for my beloved, Flowing*ln gently through*i the lips of those who fall asleep.
The Union of Love
“I*pn am my beloved’s, And*ln his desire is for me.
Come,*ln my beloved, let us go out into the country, Let*ln us spend the night in the villages.

Let*ln us rise early and*i go*i to the vineyards; Let*ln us see whether the vine has budded And*iln its*i blossoms have opened, And*iln whether*i the pomegranates have bloomed. There*ln I will give you my love.
The*ln mandrakes have given forth fragrance; And*ln over our doors are all choice fruits,*i Both*ln new and old, Which*ln I have saved up for you, my beloved.
Song of Solomon 8
The Lovers Speak
“Oh*pn that you were like a brother to me Who*ln nursed at my mother’s breasts. If*iln I found you outdoors, I would kiss you; No*ln one would despise me, either.
I*ln would lead you and*i bring you Into*ln the house of my mother, who used to instruct me; I*ln would give you spiced wine to drink from the juice of my pomegranates.
Let*ln his left hand be under my head And*ln his right hand embrace me.”
“I*ln want you to swear, O daughters of Jerusalem, Do*ln not arouse or awaken my*i love Until*ln she pleases.”

“Who*ln is this coming up from the wilderness Leaning*ln on her beloved?” “Beneath*bln the apple tree I awakened you; There*ln your mother was in labor with you, There*ln she was in labor and*i gave you birth.

Put*ln me like a seal over your heart, Like*ln a seal on your arm. For*ln love is as strong as death, Jealousy*ln is as severe as Sheol; Its*ln flashes are flashes of fire, The*ln very*i flame of the Lord.*s
Many*ln waters cannot quench love, Nor*ln will rivers overflow it; If*ln a man were to give all the riches of his house for love, It*ln would be utterly despised.”
“We*ln have a little sister, And*ln she has no breasts; What*ln shall we do for our sister On*ln the day when she is spoken for?
If*ln she is a wall, We*ln will build on her a battlement of silver; But*ln if she is a door, We*ln will barricade her with planks of cedar.”
“I*ln was a wall, and my breasts were like towers; Then*ln I became in his eyes as one who finds peace.
Solomon*ln had a vineyard at Baal-hamon; He*ln entrusted the vineyard to caretakers. Each*ln one was to bring a thousand shekels*i of silver for its fruit.
My*ln very own vineyard is at my disposal; The*ln thousand shekels*i are for you, Solomon, And*ln two hundred are for those who take care of its fruit.”
“O*ln you who sit in the gardens, My*iln companions are listening for your voice— Let*ln me hear it!”
“Hurry,*ln my beloved, And*ln be like a gazelle or a young stag On*ln the mountains of spices.”
